Situation1: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Expectation2: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation2: Before starting a large-scale project tomorrow, the carpenter needs to read and interpret blueprints, drawings, and technical documents
Story: I sit on the edge of the couch, blueprint sheets spread across my lap, lines and measurements blurring together. My partner is curled up beside me, silent tears slipping down their cheeks. I want to reach out, to hold them, to say something that will ease the ache of their loss. But the clock ticks on, and I know I have to be up early, ready to lead the team through the biggest project I’ve ever taken on. The technical documents are dense, and I haven’t even finished the first set of drawings. My mind keeps drifting—should I put the papers away and just be here, present, the way they need me? Or do I keep reading, knowing that if I mess up tomorrow, it could cost me my reputation? I feel torn in two, guilt gnawing at me no matter which way I turn. My partner’s quiet sobs make my heart ache, but the looming pressure of tomorrow’s job sits heavy on my shoulders. I can’t seem to breathe right, caught between the person I love and the work I’ve worked so hard for.
